1.author_bio: In a remarkable fusion of machine learning and neuroscience, Dwip Dalal, a talented third-year undergraduate student from IIT Gandhinagar, secured an internship at the esteemed University of British Columbia. Dwip's extraordinary project involved unraveling the enigma of decoding brain signals into behavioral video patterns using cutting-edge machine-learning techniques. Join us as we delve into Dwip's awe-inspiring journey, exploring his groundbreaking research, his passion for mathematics, and his ambitions inthe field of machine learning.
1.post_description:
I, Dwip Dalal, had the incredible opportunity to engage in a machine learning internship at the
esteemed University of British Columbia. Being deeply passionate about merging machine
learning with neuroscience, my primary objective was to delve into unexplored territory:
generating video patterns based on brain signals. To achieve this, I employed cross-modal
machine learning techniques and state-of-the-art transformer-based architectures, specifically
the Vision Transformer.
The project I embarked on involved training a model with the capability to convert brain signals
into behavioural video patterns. By meticulously analysing spike train datasets obtained from
mice equipped with implanted sensors, which recorded their daily activities and brain signals
within a controlled environment, I aimed to predict corresponding behavioural videos. For
instance, during a mouse's running activity, distinct wave patterns can be observed. This project
presented an unprecedented challenge, one that had yet to be solved, and I eagerly invested
three months of my time into unraveling this intricate puzzle.
Significantly, I am currently on the verge of publishing an extraordinary paper showcasing the
groundbreaking results of my research. Within this paper, I demonstrate my exceptional ability
to extract images that accurately represent human thoughts from intricate brain signals. My work
traverses various domains of machine learning, encompassing computer vision, natural
language processing, cross-modal learning, and the meticulous study of single modalities within
these expansive domains. Moreover, my profound fascination with mathematics has led me to
explore the captivating realm of differential machine learning.
The University of British Columbia stands as an illustrious institution revered for its excellence in
both biology and computer science. This esteemed institution proved to be the ideal
environment for conducting cutting-edge research in these fields. Immersed in a world of
profound scientific exploration, I had the invaluable opportunity to engage deeply with the study
of the brain, heart, and cellular organisms. The university's awe-inspiring museums presented
breathtaking exhibits that showcased the inherent beauty and boundless creativity of the
biological world. Additionally, I was fortunate enough to examine specimens of diverse animal
species, significantly enriching my academic experience.
Beyond the academic realm, I found myself captivated by the vibrant party culture that thrived
within the university. The presence of intellectually-driven students, characterised by their
remarkable dedication to their studies, blended harmoniously with their inclination to socialise.
This unique blend of individuals fostered an environment where learning about their research
and collaborating with them became an absolute pleasure. The students at the university
exuded friendliness, maturity, and unwavering support, forming a community that nurtured both
personal growth and academic success.
According to my observations and personal experiences, I firmly believe that those aspiring to
pursue a career in machine learning must harbor a genuine passion for mathematics or applied
mathematics. Machine learning demands a wholehearted commitment and should be treated as

a full-time endeavour. While the field is rapidly expanding, aspiring individuals may initially face
certain challenges when embarking on their journey. However, as they progress and conquer
these hurdles, the path becomes increasingly enthralling and immensely rewarding. Looking
towards the future, I envision myself pursuing a master's degree in machine learning and
venturing deeper into the realm of research.
The University of British Columbia nurtures an exceptional study culture, where study tables are
readily available in every nook and cranny. The professors at this esteemed institution are not
only remarkably knowledgeable but also remarkably approachable and supportive. They
possess an astute ability to recognise and nurture the potential in their students, going the extra
mile to assist them in achieving their goals. Additionally, the university boasts an awe-inspiring
library reminiscent of a grand museum showcasing remarkable architectural designs. The
students at UBC adeptly balance intense study sessions throughout the week with enjoyable,
well-mannered parties during the weekends, demonstrating their exceptional maturity and
unwavering dedication to both academic and social pursuits.

2.author_bio: In an inspiring blend of Theoretical Computer Science (TCS) and practical research, Nipun Mahajan, a skilled individual, ventured on a remarkable internship journey. Nipun's internships at prestigious institutions such as MathWorks and IISC Banglore have demonstrated his unwavering interest in graph algorithm design and classification challenges. Dive deeper into Nipun's extraordinary path as we highlight his major projects, research breakthroughs, and his vision for the future.
2.post_description:
My name is Nipun Mahajan, and I am a passionate individual dedicated to Theoretical
Computer Science (TCS). Ever since I embarked on my journey in the field of graph
algorithm design and classification problems, I have been filled with excitement and curiosity.
It all began during my coursework in DSA-2 when I had the privilege of learning from the
brilliant Neeldhara Mam. This course served as the foundation for my understanding of TCS
and ignited my desire to delve deeper into this captivating subject.
Throughout my educational experiences and certifications, I have constantly sought to
enhance my understanding and expertise in TCS. Completing the DSA 1 and DSA 2 courses
provided me with a solid grounding in the core concepts of TCS. Moreover, I had the
incredible opportunity to work on research projects under the guidance of esteemed
professors such as Neeldhara Ma’am, Anirban Sir, and Manoj Sir. These projects, which
involved estimating graphlets in directed graphs and computing arboricity efficiently, allowed
me to gain practical experience in algorithm design and exposed me to the intersection of
probabilistic models, algorithm design, and evaluation & testing of frameworks in TCS.
One of the most significant milestones in my journey was my internship at Mathworks, where
I focused on enhancing a software from single-core to multi-core, with a specific emphasis
on graph algorithms. This experience further solidified my understanding of graph algorithms
and their practical applications. Subsequently, during my second internship at IISC
Bangalore, I had the privilege of working on creating an algorithm for a decimal 10
processor. This opportunity expanded my knowledge in the field and enabled me to
contribute to cutting-edge research.
I have successfully applied my skills and knowledge in various projects and domains. One
project that stands out is my work on estimating graphlets in directed graphs under the
guidance of Anirban Sir. This particular project fascinated me as it provided valuable insights
into probabilistic models and the intersection of machine learning with TCS, particularly in
the context of Markov chains.
Reflecting on my most memorable experience or breakthrough moment, I vividly remember
an inspiring quote from Anirban Sir: "Reading papers in academia is like exploring the edges
of a fractal - an endless journey of discovery." This realization has been a driving force
behind my motivation to delve deeper into research in TCS. In fact, I even had the
opportunity to publish an article highlighting the journey of an undergraduate researcher and
outlining what a productive day in research looks like.
As I look towards the future, my aspiration is to continue my journey in TCS. To further
deepen my knowledge and gain practical industry experience, I have planned to spend a
year with MathWorks, a renowned company in the field. Building upon my strong
background and profile, I have been admitted to the Georgia Institute of Technology, where I
aim to continue exploring my passion. I have also received admits from other top CS
schools, including ETH Zurich, Georgia Tech, UW Madison, and Purdue. Additionally, my
dedication to TCS and involvement in various domains have allowed me to assist fellow
students in securing internships and opportunities. I cannot emphasize enough the
importance of a strong mathematical background and probabilistic foundations for success in
TCS. To aspiring students, I would advise staying updated with the field and focusing on
developing coding skills.

My journey in Theoretical Computer Science has been marked by a solid foundation in
algorithm design and practical research experience. The internships, projects, and
collaborations with esteemed professors have provided me with the opportunity to apply my
skills and knowledge in various domains. With my future aspirations firmly focused on
continued growth in TCS, I am determined to make significant contributions to the field and
inspire others to pursue careers in this thrilling area of study.

1.author_bio: Delve into the captivating world of machine learning with Prof. Nipun Batra. Their sustainability group pioneers innovative applications in energy, air quality, and health, harnessing the power of machine learning to reshape our lives. Discover their secrets to stay at the forefront of machine learning.
1.post_description:
Kindly provide a comprehensive explanation of the research problems currently being
addressed by you and your research group. Additionally, please elucidate how your
group's research will impact individuals' day-to-day lives in the future from a layman's
perspective. Furthermore, could you share examples of successful real-world
applications where the machine learning algorithms you have developed or researched
have been implemented, leveraging your expertise in Machine Learning?
Our group called the sustainability group, works on applications pertaining to energy, air quality
and health. We mostly work on machine learning problems with uncertainty. Here is a flavour of
the kind of work we do.
Air quality: A significant proportion of the Indian (and global) population is exposed to severe air
pollution leading to several diseases and loss of life. We can not reduce what we can not
accurately measure. However, the number of air quality measurement stations is significantly
lower than the required numbers. Our work develops Bayesian machine learning methods to
accurately estimate air quality at locations without any sensors. Importantly, we focus on not
only providing the predicted air quality at a location but also uncertainty estimates. We then
leverage this uncertainty to recommend where to install the next set of stations (also called
active learning) to improve the predictive performance of our models.
Health: The Apple Watch and similar wearables such as portable diabetes machines and
oxygen saturation monitors have revolutionised healthcare. We look at creating similar
wearables for estimating lung function and calorie count. We developed a mask-based system
called SpiroMask that can accurately estimate various lung health parameters using an
inexpensive system sitting at home, which earlier required a visit to a clinic. Similarly, we are
presently developing a thermal camera-based system to accurately estimate calorie burn while
exercising. Interestingly, this system is up to 25% more accurate than the Apple Watch.
Working on such healthcare applications and building applications and machine learning models
is generally hard due to the lack of participant data. We again leverage active learning to
strategically recruit participants. We have found that by using our methods, we can significantly
lower the effort required to recruit participants.
Energy: Buildings across the world consume roughly one-third of the total energy expenditure.
One way to reduce this energy is by providing occupants with feedback on their per-appliance
energy usage. This has been shown to reduce energy expenditure by up to 15%. But, we can
not install a sensor per appliance as it scales poorly in cost and maintenance effort. We
proposed techniques to disaggregate the total energy consumption (measured at the household
level using a smart meter) via machine learning into the energy consumption of constituent
appliances.
How do you think being a professor is beneficial to you while also being involved in
rapidly progressing research work?

Being a faculty is a very rewarding experience. I have always maintained that the best way to
learn is by teaching. Thus, this is one job that guarantees that one can keep improving and
learning. This role gives us the opportunity to positively impact the lives of students (future
leaders!). Being a faculty also allows us to pursue research directions that we find impactful and
interesting.
How do you stay up-to-date with the latest advancements and trends in the field of
machine learning algorithms? Are there any particular conferences, journals, or online
resources you find valuable and would suggest to the readers?
The pace of innovation in our field and times is indeed hard to keep up to pace with. I spend
dedicated time (~1-2 hours) daily morning studying some interesting machine learning
talks/lectures (mostly YouTube) and then implementing them on my research blog. This helps
me keep in touch with the theory and implementation aspects of these algorithms. Teaching
courses and keeping the courses relevant and updated also helps me in this regard. Like other
academics, I have also identified a subset of conferences in my field that I follow. To scale the
learning, attending group seminars, faculty talks, and similar events is a must!

2.discipline: Electrical Engineering with master's in Computer Science & Engineering
2.author_bio:
Yash Hiren More, a distinguished senior undergraduate student at IIT Gandhinagar, embarks on a diverse academic journey. His focal point lies in Parametrized Computational Social Choice, an intricate area where computational complexity meets group decision-making. Guided by the mentorship of

Mr. Saket Saurabh, Yash's research unveils the intricate connections between computational complexity and collective choices, This interview  encapsulates Yash's steadfast commitment, dynamic exploration, and the transformative fusion of his passion and research.
2.post_description:
I am Yash Hiren More, a senior undergraduate student in the Computer Science &
Engineering program at IIT Gandhinagar. I come from Palghar, Maharashtra, and I am
pursuing a Master's degree in Computer Science and engineering alongside my major
in Electrical Engineering for my BTech degree at IIT Gandhinagar. My academic focus
centres around algorithms, specifically Parameterized Complexity and Computational
Social Choice. I cherish quality moments spent with friends and family during my leisure
time. Additionally, I am deeply passionate about game development and online gaming,
with frequent indulgence in a game called League of Legends. This enthusiasm led my
team to secure a silver medal for game development at last year's Inter IIT Tech Meet,
further fueling my dedication to excel in this realm.
While at the Department of Informatics, University of Bergen, I was engaged in a
captivating realm of parameterised complexity and computational social choice. This
field explores the convergence of computer science and collective decision-making,
particularly investigating the challenges computers face in solving various group
decisions within specific contexts. Despite the ‘complexity', I embraced this internship
wholeheartedly, collaborating with postdoctoral researchers under Prof. Saket
Saurabh's guidance. My research was centred on comprehending the computational
complexity in a liquid democracy setting under classical as well as parameterised
scenarios, illuminating the interplay between computational efficiency and social preferences.

About my experiences in Bergen, which is considered the capital of Parameterized
Complexity I was fortunate enough to meet elite Prof. Mike Fellows who is considered
as the founder of this field. I carried my handy whiteboard to Norway.
Seeing my ideas turn into results on the whiteboard was like creating something from
scratch and feeling excited about it. PS: I was lucky to see the Aurora Borealis as well
;).
Cultivating a solid foundation is paramount for those aspiring to venture into computer
science research. This involves extensive reading, dedicated work, and a clear grasp of
concepts like NP-completeness. Focus on getting actual results, and don't be afraid of
mistakes – they're great chances to learn. Many times you’ll come across situations
where you put in endless efforts but get absolutely no results. Research is about
understanding and embracing this. There is an article by Matthew Might titled, "An
Illustrated guide to a Ph.D", which I recommend everyone pursuing research to read
once. Collaboration and seeking guidance from peers and mentors are essential for
growth. Stay curious, participate in conferences, and remain updated with the latest
advancements while adhering to ethical standards. Remember, perseverance is

critical—each obstacle surmounted brings you closer to leaving a meaningful impact on
the future of computer science.
My adventure in theoretical computer science has been a mix of curiosity and discovery.
I've learned you can create something unique by trying and staying curious. As I move
forward, I'm excited to keep exploring and learning, and I hope my story inspires others
to do the same.

3.author_bio:
Delve into Prof. Sameer Patel's
Energy, Environment, and Exposure
Laboratory (EEEL), where
interdisciplinary exploration unveils
links between energy, environment,
and human exposure. Addressing the
complex interplay, EEEL crafts
solutions to mitigate air pollution’s
health impacts while optimizing
energy usage. Join us in reshaping
sustainability paradigms.
3.post_description:
Energy, Environment, and Exposure Laboratory (EEEL)

PI: Sameer Patel, Assitant Professor, Jointly Appointed in Department of Civil Engineering and

Department of Chemical Engineering

Our research group at the Energy, Environment, and Exposure Laboratory (EEEL) conducts
interdisciplinary research on various aspects of energy, environment, and human exposure. Since
energy, environment, and human exposure are not independent, we aim to understand their
complex interdependency. Fundamental insights from our work are used to develop solutions for
mitigating the health impacts of air pollution while optimizing the associated energy penalty.

Seven million global deaths are attributed to air pollution annually, of which indoor air pollution
(IAP) is a significant contributor. People, on average, spend 80-90% of their time in some kind
of built environment, such as homes, offices, and automobiles. Therefore, exposure occurring in
indoor environments might dominate that outdoors. However, air pollution researchers,
policymakers, and media primarily focus on outdoor or ambient pollution in India. Our research
group does interdisciplinary research on different aspects of air pollution, including
measurements, modeling, and mitigation. Experimental and computational studies help us
understand the sources, transport, transformation, and fate of air pollutants in indoor spaces. We
then use the gained fundamental understanding to develop mitigation strategies to protect human
health. In addition, we also design and develop low-cost air quality monitors for real-time
measurements.

We also investigate how our air pollution mitigation strategies will affect the energy
consumption of buildings because there is usually a tradeoff between energy consumption and air
quality. This field of research is even more critical in India as we are constructing buildings
fastest globally, and energy consumption of buildings is bound to be the biggest chunk of the
nation’s total energy consumption, as is the case in many developed nations. Physics-based

modeling-based dynamic optimization strategies are evaluated in our laboratory to assess the
tradeoff between energy consumption, air quality, and thermal comfort.

Another critical aspect is to help policymakers and regulators develop a framework for
recommending guidelines for air quality in different built environments. Indoor air quality
regulations and guidelines are limited in India and globally. Multi-faceted research on pollutants,
exposure, health impacts, and commercially available mitigation technology by my research
group enable relevant stakeholders to develop practical guidelines and regulations. Further,
buildings have been given green certificates by different rating agencies. However, the building
rating methodologies lack scientific robustness and are static in nature. Moreover, indoor air
quality, which governs the health of its occupants, is given no to minimal weightage. The high
weightage given to energy consumption indirectly de-incentivizes measures for good indoor
quality, as air pollution mitigation strategies usually lead to higher energy consumption. To
address this major flaw in assessing and rating buildings, my research group also works on
developing a holistic understanding of building sustainability while accounting for tradeoffs
between human health, human comfort, and energy consumption.

4.author_bio:
In the latest edition of Quill, we
feature the remarkable journey of Mr.
Nikhil Roy, an illustrious alumnus of
IIT Gandhinagar. Hailing from Thane,
India, Nikhil's path from chemical
engineering to becoming a Research
& Development engineer at Micron's
forefront unveils a story of resilience,
exploration, and the power of seizing
opportunities. Dive into his insights
on how IITGN shaped his values,
leadership roles that left a mark, and
strategies that led him to excel in
academics, including TOEFL and GRE.
From IITGN's nurturing environment
to the world of semiconductors,
discover the valuable lessons and
advice this inspiring journey holds for
all current and upcoming scholars.
4.post_description:
Quill : August Edition (Alumni Feature : Mr.Nikhil Roy)
1)Please tell us a bit about yourself, your background, and your journey from IIT
Gandhinagar to where you are now.
Ans) I come from Thane, India. In 2018, I completed my B.Tech in Chemical Engineering
from IIT Gandhinagar. Following my undergraduate studies, I pursued further education
at the University of Florida, where I obtained a master's degree in Chemical Engineering
in 2020.
During my time at the University of Florida, I engaged in three internships. The first was
at a petroleum/polymers company called SABIC, and the subsequent two were at a
semiconductors company named Micron.
Presently, I am employed as a Research & Development engineer at Micron's
headquarters in Boise, Idaho. However, I am currently stationed at Micron's Singapore
site for a temporary work assignment.

2)How did your time at IIT Gandhinagar shape your values, skills, and overall outlook
on life and career?
Ans)I consider myself lucky to have secured an AIR of 4500-5000, which led me to IIT
Gandhinagar, instead of one of the older IITs. Looking back, my time at IIT GN was
undeniably the most enriching and enjoyable four years of my life. The college went
above and beyond to take care of its students, providing excellent facilities such as
well-furnished rooms, liberal hostel rules, and financial aid. Moreover, the institution's
approach to education introduced us to a vast world beyond mere rote learning and
academics, broadening our perspectives.
Throughout my journey at IITGN, I witnessed remarkable transformations in many of my
batchmates, who matured and grew during their time at IITGN. One of the standout
features of our college was its flexibility in terms of branch change, enabling students to
explore different interests and excel in various electives. Even if your AIR rank was not
great, the right choice of electives and self-learning could open doors to a core CS role
for a chemical engineer.
My journey at IITGN was made even more exciting by the opportunities to embark on
three foreign internships in the US, Japan, and Singapore. These experiences played a
crucial role in shaping my desire to pursue an MS abroad. The final two years of my

college life proved to be the most valuable, as I honed my leadership skills while serving
as the General Secretary, AIChE president, Class Representative and Shastrath Socratic
Society secretary.
IIT Gandhinagar provided me with an exceptional education and a platform to grow both
academically and personally. I am truly grateful for the memories and experiences that
have shaped my path ahead.

3)As the General Secretary and President of Alche, could you share some of your most
memorable experiences and achievements during your leadership roles?
Ans) Throughout our time on the student council, one of our achievements was
initiating the first-ever inter-IIT student leadership conclave. We made it a priority to be
approachable and student-friendly, and I take great pride in the fact that our student
council was successful in achieving that.
During my tenure as AICHE president, we took a step forward by creating the inaugural
prototype of Chem-E-Car, which went on to compete in various inter-college events. It
was an exciting and rewarding experience to witness our efforts come to life in such a
tangible way.

4)Students often struggle with choosing the right career path. How did you approach
this decision? Was it a process of trial and error, or did you always know you wanted to
pursue a career in your field of study?
Ans) To be honest, it was all about trial and error for me. In my opinion, the primary goal
should be to seek exposure and gather knowledge about various career possibilities,
whether it's entrepreneurship, core jobs, finance roles, or pursuing higher studies. At this
stage of my career, I am still in the early phases, and I believe it's a journey that spans
several decades, allowing room for trial and error.
Having a clear career path right from the start is fantastic, but even if you don't, don't
worry. The early years of your career offer ample opportunities to learn, explore, and
adapt. Think of it as a marathon, not a do-or-die situation. Embrace the learning process,
try different paths, and make adjustments along the way. It's all part of the journey
towards building a fulfilling and successful career.

5)Achieving excellent TOEFL and GRE scores must have been quite an
accomplishment. Could you share some tips and strategies for achieving high scores
in these exams?
Ans) I enrolled in Magoosh courses and dedicated time to practicing full-length tests
multiple times. In fact, I recommend considering taking the GRE/TOEFL exams during
your third year of study to get a head start in the application process. However, it's
important to keep in mind that GRE/TOEFL scores are primarily for gaining admission to
a specific college, and their significance diminishes afterward.
In the grand scheme of things, a slight difference in scores, like 315 vs. 330, won't have
a significant impact. Instead, I encourage you to focus on optimizing other critical
aspects of your admission package, such as strong Letters of Recommendation (LORs),
well-crafted Statements of Purpose (SOPs), notable projects, and impactful internships.
These elements carry substantial weight in your application and can greatly enhance
your chances of admission, beyond just relying on GRE scores.

6)How did you decide to pursue a Master's degree, and why did you choose the
University of Florida for your further studies?What were the major differences between
the culture at IITGN and UF?
Ans) Both IITGN and UF are excellent places. They both offer flexibility in terms of
elective courses, internships and provide ample opportunities for engaging in
extracurricular activities. In my case, I decided to attend UF primarily because I was
awarded a significant scholarship, which made it a financially convenient option.
During your final year, there might be a tendency among students to feel pressured to
secure admission to top Ivy League colleges. However, in my personal opinion,
particularly concerning pursuing a Master's degree (I cannot comment on PhDs), the
disparity between attending a US rank #10 college versus a US rank #90 college won't
significantly impact your long-term career prospects. Hence, I opted for UF, which is a
reputable college, and the scholarship simplified the financial part, making it a more
practical choice for me.

7)What opportunities did your Master's degree open up for you professionally? How
did it contribute to your career growth and aspirations?
Ans) During my Master's program, I was exposed to the world of semiconductors. This
industry is highly specialized, and only a few developed countries possess the expertise

and resources required to manufacture advanced chips. Hopefully, India will be a
semiconductor powerhouse in the near future.
At UF, I had access to a cleanroom facility where I had the opportunity to work on
lab courses and fabricate semiconductor devices. My experience at UF played a pivotal
role in opening doors for me within the semiconductor industry and our IIT alumni
helped me land my foot in the door. Presently, I am actively engaged in this field and
enjoying my work in this exciting and cutting-edge domain.
8)Based on your experiences and successes, what advice would you give to current
students and upcoming graduates as they navigate their academic and professional
journeys?
Ans) Embrace your time at IITGN and seize every opportunity to enhance your soft
skills. Learn the art of networking and engaging in conversations with people from
diverse countries and cultures. Take inspiration from skilled individuals like Atul Singh to
refine your writing abilities and excel in communication.
Seek out experiences that offer valuable exposure, such as international internships,
involvement in startups, engaging in research projects, and exploring a wide range of
extracurricular activities. Each of these experiences will contribute significantly to your
personal and professional growth, enriching your journey at IITGN and beyond.

1.title: Prof. Raghavan Ranganathan briefs about his projects and experience in Material Science Engineering
1.prof_bio: Raghavan Ranganathan is an Assistant Professor in the discipline of Material Science and Engineering at IIT Gandhinagar
1.post_description:
**Q. Can you please explain elaborately the research problems currently being addressed by you and your group? Looking from Lyman's perspective, how will your group's research effect a person's day to day life in the future? How do you think being a professor is beneficial to you while also being involved in rapidly progressing research work?**

Whenever I think of the trajectory of cutting-edge Materials research, I am reminded of the famous motto of the Olympics, “Citius, Altius, Fortius” that encourages Olympians to aim for faster, higher and stronger performance. Materials development has been one of the best yardsticks of technological progress attested to by the naming of civilizational ages starting from the prehistoric stone age times, to bronze, iron, steel ages, and what we now call the silicon age. If one observes keenly, one can easily perceive that we have always tried to make our materials stronger, lighter, and simply, better in every conceivable way. Indeed, this pursuit has only progressed at breakneck speed in the 21st century, driven by a plethora of variables such as consumerism, defense and military applications, medical applications, etc., to name a few. In fact, the addition of a fourth word, “Communiter”, to the Olympics motto in 2021 that emphasizes togetherness is even more apt for Materials research - we want materials to have all the desirable properties together, or at the same time!

At the Computational Molecular Engineering Group (CMEG) at IITGN, we work on advanced simulations of material structure, properties and design, with a view to understanding the complex relationships between them. These simulations make use of realistic descriptions of material interactions across various length and time scales, and when combined with appropriate input conditions and computational resources to run them on (mind you, simulating materials at the nanoscale (that is, a time scale of 1 nanosecond and a length scale of 1 nanometer may well take over several days!), yield an unprecedented level of detail that cannot be achieved through experimentation. This naturally accelerates the discovery, design and development of novel materials and is crucial for the success of programs such as the Materials Genome Initiative.

I will highlight some of our ongoing projects briefly. The first is perhaps one of the oldest fields of Materials, alloy development. Here, we model novel, multi-component alloys (made up of several alloying additions) with a range of material defects and elucidate the role played by these defects on the mechanical properties of the alloy. We make use of state-of-the-art atomistic simulations and machine learning techniques to describe the interaction of the atoms and defects and to explain the mechanisms responsible for their observed properties. This has important implications for high-strength, high-toughness materials with applications in defense, aerospace and structural components. The second project looks into mechanisms of Lithium diffusion in modern Lithium ion batteries from the lens of computational materials science. To ensure optimum performance and safety of the battery, there has been an exciting push internationally to develop novel battery materials with superior properties and our group is pursuing some fundamental research in this direction. Thirdly, a focus of our group is to engineer materials that are inspired by nature, a field known as biomimetics. To give some perspective, natural materials such as spider silk, nacre (the inner lining of an oyster shell), bone, gecko’s feet, etc. have fascinating properties such as exceptional specific strength, toughness, adhesive properties and the like. We build atomistic models of these materials to understand the interplay between the structure and property that are helping us in predicting new design rules and eventually, development and deployment of these materials for various applications.

Finally, being a Professor has been immensely beneficial to me personally in several respects and I am sure all faculty members share this sentiment. Working on cutting-edge research projects broadens one’s understanding of our world and gives us a lot of food for thought in this complex and intricate world that we live in. The joy of teaching is another very important aspect that cannot be put into words. Although it can definitely be daunting to keep pace with rapidly changing theories, ideas and methodologies, striking a good balance between research, teaching and other forms of service is a truly rewarding, but most importantly, a humbling experience.

addressed by you and your research group. Additionally, please elucidate how your
group's research will impact individuals' day-to-day lives in the future from a layman's
perspective. Furthermore, could you share examples of successful real-world
applications where the machine learning algorithms you have developed or researched
have been implemented, leveraging your expertise in Machine Learning?_

Our group called the sustainability group, works on applications pertaining to energy, air quality
and health. We mostly work on machine learning problems with uncertainty. Here is a flavour of
the kind of work we do.
Air quality: A significant proportion of the Indian (and global) population is exposed to severe air
pollution leading to several diseases and loss of life. We can not reduce what we can not
accurately measure. However, the number of air quality measurement stations is significantly
lower than the required numbers. Our work develops Bayesian machine learning methods to
accurately estimate air quality at locations without any sensors. Importantly, we focus on not
only providing the predicted air quality at a location but also uncertainty estimates. We then
leverage this uncertainty to recommend where to install the next set of stations (also called
active learning) to improve the predictive performance of our models.
Health: The Apple Watch and similar wearables such as portable diabetes machines and
oxygen saturation monitors have revolutionised healthcare. We look at creating similar
wearables for estimating lung function and calorie count. We developed a mask-based system
called SpiroMask that can accurately estimate various lung health parameters using an
inexpensive system sitting at home, which earlier required a visit to a clinic. Similarly, we are
presently developing a thermal camera-based system to accurately estimate calorie burn while
exercising. Interestingly, this system is up to 25% more accurate than the Apple Watch.
Working on such healthcare applications and building applications and machine learning models
is generally hard due to the lack of participant data. We again leverage active learning to
strategically recruit participants. We have found that by using our methods, we can significantly
lower the effort required to recruit participants.
Energy: Buildings across the world consume roughly one-third of the total energy expenditure.
One way to reduce this energy is by providing occupants with feedback on their per-appliance
energy usage. This has been shown to reduce energy expenditure by up to 15%. But, we can
not install a sensor per appliance as it scales poorly in cost and maintenance effort. We
proposed techniques to disaggregate the total energy consumption (measured at the household
level using a smart meter) via machine learning into the energy consumption of constituent
appliances.

_How do you think being a professor is beneficial to you while also being involved in
rapidly progressing research work?_

Being a faculty is a very rewarding experience. I have always maintained that the best way to
learn is by teaching. Thus, this is one job that guarantees that one can keep improving and
learning. This role gives us the opportunity to positively impact the lives of students (future
leaders!). Being a faculty also allows us to pursue research directions that we find impactful and
interesting.
How do you stay up-to-date with the latest advancements and trends in the field of
machine learning algorithms? Are there any particular conferences, journals, or online
resources you find valuable and would suggest to the readers?
The pace of innovation in our field and times is indeed hard to keep up to pace with. I spend
dedicated time (~1-2 hours) daily morning studying some interesting machine learning
talks/lectures (mostly YouTube) and then implementing them on my research blog. This helps
me keep in touch with the theory and implementation aspects of these algorithms. Teaching
courses and keeping the courses relevant and updated also helps me in this regard. Like other
academics, I have also identified a subset of conferences in my field that I follow. To scale the
learning, attending group seminars, faculty talks, and similar events is a must!

1.title: ##Invent@IITGN 2019 Experience - Praveen
1.post_description:
Towards the end of my freshman year, early in February 2019, I decided that I wanted to work on something productive during my summer vacations. After a temporarily spiked interest in the Explorers Fellowship succeeding the application deadline, I got to know about Invent@IITGN when I noticed that one of my seniors had a patent in his junior year. Further, when I read about this program, I instantly knew that I wanted to apply for it. Since I was in school, I always had an interest in tearing items apart to observe how everyday objects work. I used to disassemble broken telephones, speakers, etc. and tried to reverse engineer it. Towards the end, I at least turned them on. It was this curious and inquisitive nature of mine that got me excited to join this programme! As a kid, I distinctly remember telling my parents that I wanted to be an "inventor" once I grew up, and the programme was a way in which I could let my imagination run wild, and actually "Invent" something.


In the first few days of the programme, we formed random teams and constructed a Rube Goldberg machine, and also assembled a massive structure on a wall called "WonderStructs". It was a "find your partner" activity, as we had to invent our product in teams of two. In the coming weeks, we went from finding a problem to solve to finalizing the problem and solution, to prototyping version 1 using a can of pringles, and to finally finishing our product at prototype version 7.


Initially, when we were researching for problems to solve, we had many ideas in mind. However, we came to know that a lot of these already existed, and/or were already products. Invent@IITGN aimed to make something that no one in the world has ever thought. In the beginning, this was exciting but quickly became exhausting. We had over 20 ideas for a new product, but almost all of them were not feasible to be designed within seven weeks. After intense brainstorming, we came up with the idea of creating a device that could help people who couldn't use their hands.


The device that we initially proposed was a robotic arm which would scoop food from a plate and feed it to you. The significant difference between the proposed and other existing arms was that this arm would be driven using some mechanical energy, thus will be entirely mechanical. However, this idea wasn't very well received by our mentors, and we ended up creating a much simpler design which was a vast improvement from other products that existed in the market. Over the seven different prototypes we built, a lot of functionality changed. We eventually managed to reduce the number of moving parts in our design along with reducing the number of electronic components, thus reducing the cost of our device by more than 1000%. Our solution had also made the device portable and user-friendly.


What was better was the fact that it had a tremendous impact on the global patient market. Millions of people around the world are affected by conditions such as ALS, Parkinson's Disease, Alzheimer's Disease, Amputations, Surgeries, Genetic disorders, Cerebral Palsy and many more. Almost all of these conditions affect the use of the patients' hand. Therefore, the patient will need the help of a caretaker to perform even basic tasks such as eating, which often leads to a sense of low self-esteem. This is also quite demeaning in a social gathering. FoodBuddy (as we called it) can significantly change their lifestyle and prevent unwanted emotional distress to an already stressed patient. This is achieved by giving back control of the patient's life by easing out the simple task of eating independently.


Towards the end of the program, we filled out a provisional patent application. We filed it with the Indian patent office as well as the US patent office. In the coming future, we would like to improve the product further and release the product into the market.


During these long and exciting seven weeks that I spent in AB 6-202, I had a lot of fun! Apart from actually inventing something, we had a fun activity every weekend. On one of the weeks, we played random games with balloons and paper planes. Another week we went to Ahmedabad to play paintball. During the entire period of Invent@IITGN, I can't forget the virtually unlimited food that all of us were drooling over.


I learnt a lot of things by participating at Invent@IITGN. My presentation skills, verbal and written communication skills vastly improved, and I had found myself a large group of friends who have similar interests. Most importantly, I learnt that it is fine to fail. During the programme, we failed several times. From being favourites in one week to being hated another week, I learnt how to fail, and how to bounce back in style.


Overall, the entire experience was incredible, and if asked, I would instantly recommend anyone to apply for this programme.
1.student_bio: Praveen Venkatesh is a Sophomore in Electrical Engineering at IIT Gandhinagar. You can drop him an email at praveen.venkatesh@iitgn.ac.in

2.title: Invent@IITGN 2019 Experience - Arpita
2.post_description:
Invent@IIITGN had been a wonderful experience. Can you believe the fact that you can invent something in just six weeks? Yes, you can!  Invent@IITGN is the replication of the Invention Factory run at the Cooper Union, New York under the guidance of Professor Alan Wolf (Physics) and Professor Eric Lima (Mechanical Engineering). It began in India in 2018 with IIT Gandhinagar to be the first institute to host it.  

Here, I share my experience at Invent@IITGN 2019.

Why did I register for Invent? The three-month-long summer break is the best opportunity for anyone to develop new skills and explore his/her areas of interest by hands-on experimentations. I knew that this time span would  not be utilised efficiently if I were to stay at home. Sometime in February, a mail flashed asking for applications for Invent@IITGN, Summer 2019. The idea of this intensive six-week summer programme is to investigate a real-life problem, and propose and prototype a solution for the same. This very same idea sparked my interest immediately and I applied for the same. Doubtfully, I applied and fortunately, I got selected to be one of the 28 members at Invent@IITGN 2019. 

Students from various IITs such as Bombay, Guwahati, Madras, Palakkad, Dharwad, Dhanbad and Goa took part in the programme along with seven students from IIT Gandhinagar. I had just completed my first year, but students who had completed their second, third and even fourth year were a part of Invent@IITGN.
Invent is not merely a programme, it is a competition where the best inventors receive decent prize money, where there are groups of two, who work on filing a provisional patent till the journey ends. 

So, here begins the process of ideation, prototyping and pitching. The day one was quite exciting for everyone with many unknown faces all around, everyone with different expectations and interests. The programme began with a basic orientation of a few useful softwares, the 3-D printing and laser cutting machines which we would be using extensively. Our first task was to assemble a miniature Rube Goldberg Machine from a Wonderstruct kit.  It was a fun task which required some coordination and high precision. We were able to assemble the entire structure on the wall by 4 am the next day. Enervated till the end, I thought about whether the programme would be tiring for me. And this was the last time I thought this. Here is a snapshot of the Wonderstruct assembly!


 

The professors from Cooper Union, Alan and Eric (as we used to call them) joined us in the first week. They were our mentors along with Prof Madhu, Prof Vineet and Prof Nithin George from IITGN. We were supposed to form our teams in the first week itself. I paired up with Lipika Gupta, a Bachelor of Design student from IIT Guwahati who had just completed her second year. 

The ideation began by forming groups of similar interests and discussing problems relevant to those interests. By the end of the first week, each team had to present their problem and a rudimentary yet unique solution in front of other teams and mentors. The teams with the most convincing ideas would get an upvote, a green signal to go ahead and others were required to either ponder a little more upon defining the problem and solution or change the problem. I’ve noticed that people often jump to solutions while ideating, like matching questions to answers. Definitely, this is not the right approach, a worthy problem will bring up a desirable solution. A tip from my experience: Always look into your surroundings for problems, think about certain difficulties your family and friends might be facing, you are always diligent to solve such problems. 

Both me and my partner were keen on solving certain problems pertaining to the elderly. Initially, we thought of working with wheelchairs and modifying them to make them a little more user-friendly. Another idea was to make a portable ramp as every place is not accessible for wheelchair aided people, but such a product already existed in the market. After spending entirely two days on looking for problems that the elderly or disabled usually face, we realized that there is a very little scope for us to do something in six weeks in this area. With only a day left for our first presentation, we started ideating again from the beginning, thinking of various other problems. 

While ideating we followed various techniques like SCAMPER and brainstormed to come up with a variety of problems. Sticky notes, empty walls and a notebook always helped in ideating. We finally came up with the idea to organise the medications of the elderly. They often mess up with their medicines and sometimes forget consuming them. An assistant is always required to take care of the medication routines/schedules. Our idea was to come up with an automatic pill dispenser that rings an alarm when medicines are to be taken. The alarm needs to be turned off by the user and that particular dose comes out in a tray. And yeah, we were upvoted!

For the rest of the weeks, we changed the mechanisms of operating the device, searched for various existing patents (Lipika studied a hell lot of existing patents while I was figuring out how to operate the Arduino!), studied a lot about patent law (thanks to Alan for this), gave presentations to guest panels comprising of professionals working in different areas. This helped us a lot in learning something new or novel every other day. The guest presentations each week helped us in identifying the flaws in our concept and prototype, and it was always enriching to get an expert’s advice on your invention.  Working in a team teaches division of labour, makes you an avid listener and improves your ability in conveying information precisely. It also provides you with new perspectives to think and proceed. 

One fine day, just before Week 3’s guest presentations, we found an existing device similar to ours. Patents can be filed successfully only if the device presents a unique concept or is a non-obvious combination of two or more existing devices. This was a big problem!
After discussing the problem with the mentors, we came up with an idea to monitor the cognitive health of the user along with their medication routine. This made our device more focussed to elderly people suffering from dementia. The cognitive health was monitored by a simple task which the user had to perform every time to get the medicines. We did not find a single existing device monitoring a person’s cognitive health at home!

Along with improving technical skills, Invent helped me in developing technical writing skills and presentation skills. Your invention might be very useful for society, but unless you convey the essence of your invention to the person in front of you, which might be through words, it is worthless. We significantly improved our speech rate, and I especially learned how to convey information in a minimum number of words. You significantly improve your ability to converse. You learn Jugaad!


This is something Lipika always insisted while making a dummy prototype. Look around and identify how any material, any object can help you in your prototype. Grab it, try it and test it. 

Apart from the invention, we did a hell lot of fun with all of these little known faces. Every weekend we did something recreational. Once there was a movie evening followed by pizzas, and we sane people ended up watching Deadpool. On another weekend we went out for a paintball game which was an unforgettable experience. There was a Gala Dinner in which many guest evaluators and people from different domains were invited for you to connect with. On one of the weekends, Eric organised recreational competitions for us. 

Robokits was our new general store. Apart from everything, we were engaged in a lot of networking. People from different IITs brought their culture, ideas and experiences for a competition worth to give learnings for a lifetime. Invent was amazing and I would recommend it resolutely.
2.student_bio: Arpita Kabra is a Sophomore in Electrical Engineering at IIT Gandhinagar. You can drop her an email at arpita.kabra@iitgn.ac.in

3.title: Invent@IITGN 2019 Experience - Chris
3.post_description:
Why did I choose Invent@IITGN?

I came to know about Invent through a senior’s profile where I noticed that he had filed a provisional patent application for an invention through this program. I explored more and got interested to take part in this program. Making things has always been one of my interests. Invent@IITGN was an excellent opportunity to take that interest to a higher level. That is the prime reason why I chose to apply for Invent@IITGN instead of the Explorer’s Fellowship.

Another thing that inspired me to apply for it was videos of the inventions from previous editions. Invent@IITGN has paved the way for some innovative inventions like an anti-tremor spoon for people with essential tremor, an origami-inspired spill-resistant cup and more.

The most exciting part was that we could file a provisional patent application through the event. IIT Gandhinagar may later fund the entire non-provisional patent application procedure if it seems worth it. 

What did I try to invent?

My teammate Praveen and I invented an assistive dining device that helps people without operable arms to eat food. It scoops food from a plate and lifts it to the user’s mouth. It uses less components than other motorized devices in the market that serve the same purpose. We were able to reduce the number of motors by using slots on the device to direct the spoon as we required. We also made it voice-enabled and reduced its size to that of a bottle and a tray. 
The first week of the program was for ideation. The idea for a feeding device was among one of our first ideas. It was a difficult task to come up with problems. We knew that it was the most crucial part. We were confident of creating the solution somehow, but deciding what to solve took some amount of brainstorming.

How can it make an impact in the world or on the community?

It is an assistive dining device that comes under Rs. 5000. Existing solutions are worth 4000-5000 USD, which is approximately Rs. 3 lakhs. Our invention can make assistive dining affordable to everyone. 
It helps people without arms to eat without feeling inferior to others. It is portable and has a non-obtrusive design. It allows people to use it wherever they go without drawing too much attention. 

What now?

We have decided to continue working on it so that it can be made more portable. We plan on making the tray foldable and designing it such that the bottle can be inserted into the folded tray. We also need to revise the design through a series of testing. After that, we wish to file a non-provisional patent application in India and USA. We also want to present our idea at other competitions and events. It will help us in refining the product further and in raising funds for it.

What essential and/or indispensable skills Invent@IITGN taught me?

Invent@IITGN immensely improved my technical skills. I gained experience in laser-cutting, 3D printing and computer-aided design (CAD) software like Autodesk Fusion 360 and Keyshot. It also gave me some amount of exposure to Internet of Things (IoT), as we worked on voice-enabling the device through IFTTT, Amazon Alexa and Google Assistant. We also learnt basic patent law and how to write a provisional patent application. We wrote our provisional patent applications ourselves. 

However, the most crucial skill that Invent@IITGN taught me was the importance of presentation. Presenting your work well is equally important as the work itself. We had four presentations before the final presentation. These helped me drastically improve my presentation skills. Invent@IITGN also taught me how things depend a lot on critical moments. If you miss those moments, all the effort and time you put in may suddenly seem a lot less compelling. 

What was the best part of it?

There is nothing I can claim to be the best part of Invent@IITGN. The entire program was filled with things that could tie for first place on the list of bests. I got to make some lifelong friends of different ages and residences. We became really good friends in six weeks. I had more fun with them in six weeks than I ever had in the past year. I got to be close friends with people who were my seniors. Talking with people from other IITs gave me new ideas and inspirations. I got to know about how events are conducted in different IITs. We all helped each other. I also got to know some of my professors closely. We talked a lot with our mentors - Prof. Alan Wolf, Prof. Eric Lima, Prof. Nithin V. George, Prof. Madhu Vadali and Prof. Vineet Vashista. 
The first two days of the program were for learning the basics of laser-cutting and 3D printing. We made a wall-mounted Wonderstructs structure on the first day in the room allotted for the program. We also made a table-top Rube-Goldberg Machine (Here’s the link: https://www.facebook.com/invent.iitgn/videos/2400797743485497/). We had a lot of fun together. We had a paint-ball fight on a Sunday and a networking dinner with the professors, guest evaluators and donors. It was a wholesome experience.
3.student_bio: Chris Francis is a Sophomore in Computer Science and Engineering at IIT Gandhinagar. You can drop him an email at chris.francis@iitgn.ac.in

4.title: ##Invent@IITGN 2019 - Jay
4.post_description:
Why did I choose Invent@IITGN?

Being interested in technical projects, Invent@IITGN was one of the best opportunities I could have got. It provided me with a platform to work with peers across different IITs and also helped me in an all-round personality development. It was not only a great place to work but also to have fun at the same time. By the end of six weeks, we were asked to file both an Indian and a US Provisional Patent Application from the work we do in the meantime. 

I wanted to invent something that would help society! 
I wanted to see the world from a different perspective!

What did I try to invent?

Initially, Souritra and I had many ideas which we wanted to build on, but at the back of our mind, we always wanted to go for something that would be helpful to others. After brainstorming for around a week and a half, we drafted a problem statement. Prof. Alan Wolf and Prof. Eric Lima helped us a lot during this problem drafting period. 

Souritra and I decided to Invent a Smart Visor, a  device for automobile drivers, to prevent them from being blind due to a direct or prompt sight of the sun. The device includes a housing which in turn includes a camera, two motors, and a microcontroller. The housing sits on top of the car’s dashboard, close to the windshield and laterally centred on the windshield. A telescopic arm protrudes from the housing, extends vertically upwards and terminates in a circular neutral density filter of a particular size. This size is kept such that it’s just appropriate to block intense sunlight directed to the driver’s eyes. The microcontroller processes the camera’s output and uses this data to determine the motions of the motor. This aids to place the filter at an optimum position for the driver’s comfort. The motors cause the telescopic arm both to rotate like a windshield wiper and extend and retract so as to put the filter at the best position.

How can it make an impact?

The target audience of our product is people with light coloured eyes in mid-latitude countries. Sun rises at a lower altitude in these countries making the traditional sun visors ineffective. This is a serious problem for people with light coloured eyes who are extremely sensitive to the sun’s sight. Direct sunlight may completely overwhelm them which may lead to catastrophes

What now?

We are planning to make it more compact and more user-friendly. Making it cheaper might render the product more accessible to a wider audience, especially in the west. We shall try to commercialize and market it on social media platforms.

What essential and/or indispensable skills Invent@IITGN taught me?

Invent @ IITGN taught me presentation skills, which is a very important skill for becoming an entrepreneur. We learnt how to pitch our idea to the guest evaluators. These evaluators are generally prominent industrialists. I also learnt teamwork, time management and many more skills in both technical and non-technical domains.

What was the best part of it?

Invent@IITGN provided me with an opportunity to work with peers from other IITs, which was the best part of it.

The network we made by meeting different guest evaluators every week, and the communication with the experts on the final day of judgement was one of the best things about being a part of Invent@IITGN. We also filed an Indian Provisional Patent and a US provisional Patent which I think itself is a huge achievement.

Without the help of Prof. Alan Wolf, Prof Eric, Prof. Madhu Vadali, Prof. Nitin George and Prof. Vineet Vashist, it wouldn’t have been possible to achieve such a great thing in such a short duration.
4.student_bio: Jay Shah is a Sophomore in Chemical Engineering at IIT Gandhinagar. You can drop him an email at jay.shah@iitgn.ac.in
